messageBody:
I probably started using it for local variables after
reading Joshua Bloch's Effective Java although I can't
rapidly find a specific paragraph to cite as a
recommendation to use it.

I don't use it quite as much as it seems Mike Bowler
does (the HtmlUnit coding conventions rather emphasize
it). I have started experimenting with using it for
parameter declarations after exploring HtmlUnit a bit
but haven't reached a conclusion for my own habits).

I do find it helps clarify my intent about a local
variable particularly in large methods. (My current
contract has me working on some pretty "procedural"
Java code and it's not always appropriate to jump in
and refactor until the methods are all nice and
small.) Using final for local variables in these big
methods makes it clear to anyone reading the code that
the variable is expected to at least be predictable as
to what object or value it refers to for the rest of
the method. The only thing I expect the compiler to
do with it is enforce the "set once" property just in
case I or anyone else forgets that they shouldn't set
it again.

I'm not sure it helps much when methods are small but
I do find that I'm starting to put it in even with
small methods just to be consistent.

Doing it because it might help the compiler generate
better code hasn't tempted me. I guess I suspect that
if I have a performance problem in a method, I won't
fix it just by giving the compiler a hint like final.
I expect I'd have to think harder about how to reduce
the cost of the work being performed in that method
and perhaps it's neighbors in the call stack.
